Message.Title: I feel sorry for....
Message.Msg: investors who bought in the $20s-$30s. Honestly, if Mr. Dell would have been patient, and let all the new branch outs into the business world take hold and pan out, the pps of this stock would get back into the 20's and 30's. Also, PC's wont go away. Look, poor people cant afford APPLE's computers, but they can afford Dell's. There are always going to be poor people, and always a need for a cheaper PC. Also this tablet mess is a fad. I for one hate them. Id rather have a desk top or laptop in front of me any day. I like to look at bigger screens and actually have real keys that I can punch. Oh sure, you can buy a tablet and gadgets/accessories that goes with it like a keyboard, but in the end what has the tablet turned into.....a freakin PC!!!! Also, I guarantee the APPLE craze will burn out one day. Oh sure, its cool to have anything made by Apple, but come on, trends have a limited life span. All major tech companies ride on waves. Apple was on top back in the 80's, then they hibernated for a while, and now they have woke up. Activision did the same thing. Dells doing the same thing. SO my point is, its not fair to the 20-30 pps investors that cry baby Mr. Dell was sitting in a corner one day, with a snot bubble in his nose,and poopy diapers on, pouting about how low the pps was and the scrutiny of WS and the news, and then deciding....ILL SHOW THEM, ILL TAKE THIS PRIVATE!!! NANNY NANNY BOO BOO STICK YOURE HEAD IN DOO-DOO PPPTTTHHHHH!!!!!! Look, Im not an investor at 20 or 30, so this isnt a biased rant. Im in at 9.80 something, but I feel for all of you investors getting screwed by this deal. I hope this deal falls apart, and the pps crashes, giving you an opportunity to double down, and get back to even. Also, maybe that would give Mr. Dell sometime to re-consider and stay the course. If he would stay patient and fight the good fight, eventually Wall Street and the news people would be proven wrong, (which we all know a stock will pop even more for that one reason alone), and Dell would be near the top again. Good luck to all

Message.Title: MD has an axe to grind...
Message.Msg: b/c if the deal doesn't go through, then you essentially have the CEO and biggest shareholder putting a stake in the ground at whatever the offer price is (not to mention that there's a premium built into that, which goes away without a deal). So, if it's too low, then he/Sliver Lake have essentially put a ceiling on the future market value, b/c if the CEO/major shareholder and the rest of the LBO team doesn't think it's worth more than that price, then who ELSE is going to want pay a higher price. In other words, if the deal goes south, then a $13 price implies that the stock isn't worth more than $10, which would suck for shareholders (including MD) if the deal doesn't work out.

Topic.Title: explain to me how this buyout will work

Message.Msg: Every merger and, or, acqisition involving a public company has litigation. Lawyers bring class action suits to try and discover improprieties. If it is a large dollar deal, a dozen or more law firsm may file suit. What they are after is a settlement from which they can collect fees. The settlement/fees are paid by the involved companies insurance companies. None of the above has anything to do with the acquisition price and, or common shareowners receiving any compensation. It is just legal action so law firms may collect fees for their firms. As for the acquisition price Dell's Board of Directors has an obligation to justify the price is fair. In this case, the final six months of 2012 trading in Dell stock, at an average price of about $10 to $10.50, is more than sufficient evidence to prove that a $12 to $12.50 buyout price is more than adequate compensation for common shareowners. Hope this helps.

Topic.Title: HOW CAN THEY HOODWINK A 25.00 STOCK PLUS FOR 14.00

Message.Msg: Dell was a $25 stock years and years ago. much has changed since then including more competition, software functionality, electronic computing device evolution etc... etc.... These changes are why DELL stock, for much of last year , traded below $10 per share. The company's business has been down trending for several years now. A LBO at $12 or $12.50 gives common stockholders an opportunity to exit the company at a much higher prance than had been available to them for quite sometime. And, as a private company DELL will be able to execute business strategy changes and suffer short term bottomline losses while outside of public view. If management is able to transform the company, and once again have business divisions with positive sales trend momentum, then at that time Dell may choose to again become a public company. I expect that would be a minimum of 5 years from now.

Message.Title: Fiduciary duty meaningless
Message.Msg: Fiduciary duties require that the fiduciary acts solely in the best interest of the employer/principal, free of any self-dealing, conflicts of interest, or other abuse of the principal for personal advantage. Thus, corporate directors, officers, and employees are barred from using corporate property or assets for their personal pursuits, or taking corporate opportunities for themselves

Message.Title: Breach of fiduciary duty
Message.Msg: An individual in whom another has placed the utmost trust and confidence to manage and protect property or money. The relationship wherein one person has an obligation to act for another's benefit. A fiduciary relationship encompasses the idea of faith and confidence and is generally established only when the confidence given by one person is actually accepted by the other person. Mere respect for another individual's judgment or general trust in his or her character is ordinarily insufficient for the creation of a fiduciary relationship. The duties of a fiduciary include loyalty and reasonable care of the assets within custody. All of the fiduciary's actions are performed for the advantage of the beneficiary.
